required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Sensitizing Potential of Diacerein 1% Ointment in Healthy Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Controlled Study to Evaluate the Sensitizing Potential of CCP-020 (Diacerein 1%) Topical Ointment in Healthy Subjects Using a Repeat Insult Patch Test Design

brief_summary.textblock: Single center, randomized, controlled, evaluator blinded, within-subject study to evaluate the sensitization potential of diacerein 1% ointment under occlusive conditions on normal skin of healthy volunteer subjects.

detailed_description.textblock: The study was designed to assess the sensitization potential of diacerein 1% ointment in comparison to vehicle ointment and 0.9% saline (negative irritant control) under occlusive patch conditions, at 3 randomly assigned, adjacent skin sites, 3 times weekly for 3 weeks (9 applications) during the Induction Phase, and one time during the Challenge Phase (10 times in total) for determining sensitization potential.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All subjects were exposed to diacerein 1% ointment, vehicle ointment, and 0.9% saline (negative control) at 3 randomly assigned, adjacent skin sites on the infrascapular area of the back 3 times weekly for 3 weeks (9 applications) during the Induction Phase, and one time during the Challenge Phase (10 times in total).

primary_outcome.description: The determination of dermal sensitization potential was based on the recurrence of a cutaneous response at re-challenge that was equivalent or more severe than the cumulative irritation score observed during the challenge period. Cumulative irritation score is a visual score rating the degree of erythema, edema, and other signs of cutaneous irritation: Minimum = 0; Maximum = 6; higher score is worse outcome.

intervention.description: All subjects were exposed to diacerein 1% ointment, vehicle ointment, and 0.9% saline (negative control) at 3 randomly assigned, adjacent skin sites on the infrascapular area of the back 3 times weekly for 3 weeks (9 applications) during the Induction Phase, and one time during the Challenge Phase (10 times in total).

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Observed Sensitization
outcome.description: The determination of dermal sensitization potential was based on the recurrence of a cutaneous response at re-challenge that was equivalent or more severe than the cumulative irritation score observed during the challenge period. Cumulative irritation score is a visual score rating the degree of erythema, edema, and other signs of cutaneous irritation: Minimum = 0; Maximum = 6; higher score is worse outcome.
outcome.population: The evaluation of sensitization was based on all subjects who completed the Challenge Phase of the study.

Cumulative irritation score is a visual score rating the degree of erythema, edema, and other signs of cutaneous irritation: Minimum = 0; Maximum = 6; higher score is worse outcome.

reported_events.desc: Adverse events were not assessed at a patch site-specific level.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: There were no limitations or caveats in this study.
